titleStmt.title: To the woorshipfull my very lo∣uing Cosen M. Thomas Rickarde of Hatfield-chase, in Yorkeshire.
titleStmt.author: G., C.

publicationStmt.publisher: To the Reader: The English Preface in Print, c. 1475-1640 / Early English Books Online Text Creation Partnership

analytic.title: To the woorshipfull my very lo∣uing Cosen M. Thomas Rickarde of Hatfield-chase, in Yorkeshire.
analytic.author: G., C.

div.head: To the woorshipfull my very louing Cosen M. Thomas Rickarde of Hatfield-chase, in Yorkeshire.
div.p: GOod cosen, not any desert of mine owne woorth, but hoping to be countenanced by your woorthines, maketh me thus bould to relye on your acceptance of this idle woorke, compounded (as the French nod) of sundry fashions, a thing (which if it proue pleasing to you in the least respect) I shall thinke it valuable to my cost and labour: I doe not doubt but as alwayes you haue looued me, so you will not now reiect this instance of my zealous affection which I haue had from my cradle to gratifie you, protesting (if you wil boulster me in this) neuer to step so farre into the presse agayne, and thus withall respectiue ceremonies I take my leaue.

closer.signed: Your louing Cosen C. G. Gent.
